channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Court upholds Newsom's coronavirus ban on in-person church services in California
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld California Gov. Gavin Newsom's ban on in-person church services due to the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld California Gov. Gavin Newsom's ban on in-person church services due to the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Wally Thomas of Lake Forest and Denean MacAndrew of Mission Viejo take part in a protest in Huntington Beach on May 9, 2020.

item.title: A new coronavirus testing site is opening at Dodger Stadium: What you need to know
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti announced a new coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium. Here's what you need to know.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti announced a new coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium. Here's what you need to know.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MARCH 26, 2020: The public entrance to Dodger Stadium is closed on what would have been opening day if not for the coronavirus outbreak. At far right is an employee entrance. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County cleared to reopen more businesses amid coronavirus restrictions
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Hannah Fry
item.description: Orange County has been approved by the state to mount a more aggressive reopening of local businesses amid the coronavirus, officials said Saturday.
item.content:encoded: Orange County has been approved by the state to mount a more aggressive reopening of local businesses amid the coronavirus, officials said Saturday.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2020. Cops and protesters find a shady spot along Pacific Coast Highway in Laguna Beach on Saturday, May 2, 2020. California Gov. Gavin Newson ordered a hard closure of Orange County beaches this weekend. But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California just made it easier for bars, wineries, distilleries to offer to-go drinks
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: More California establishments can sell alcoholic beverages to go after the state relaxed a rule to help businesses during the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: More California establishments can sell alcoholic beverages to go after the state relaxed a rule to help businesses during the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Bartender Taylor Osorio wears a face mask as she pours drinks at Centro Cocina Mexicana restaurant in Sacramento, Calif., Friday, May 22, 2020. As part of Sacramento County's extended Stage 2 reopening plan, dine-in restaurants and retail stores were allowed to open at noon Friday after being closed for several months due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: How L.A. County became coronavirus epicenter: Slower shutdown, density, poverty among theories
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Theories abound as to why L.A. County has the bulk of the state's confirmed coronavirus cases, but a clear explanation has been elusive.
item.content:encoded: Theories abound as to why L.A. County has the bulk of the state's confirmed coronavirus cases, but a clear explanation has been elusive.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti speaks during a Los Angeles County Health Department press conference on the novel coronavirus, (COVID-19)on March 4, 2020 in Los Angeles, California, along with Los Angeles County Public Health director Barbara Ferrer(L) and Supervisor Hilda Solis(2ndR). - Stressing that they were acting out of "an abundance of caution" Los Angeles County officials today declared a state of emergency for the novel coronavirus, as six new cases of the disease were revealed in the county in the last 48 hours. (Photo by Robyn Beck / AFP) (Photo by ROBYN BECK/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Memorial Day brings heat and warnings on outings amid coronavirus in Southern California
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Colleen Shalby, Hannah Fry, Luke Money
item.description: Many Southern California parks, beaches and trails will be open over Memorial Day weekend, but social distancing is being urged amid the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Many Southern California parks, beaches and trails will be open over Memorial Day weekend, but social distancing is being urged amid the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: This was the view from Venice Beach north toward Santa Monica on the morning that L.A. County reopened its beaches after closure because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Massive fire strikes San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf, spares WWII ship
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A fire broke out before dawn on San Francisco's Pier 45 and tore through a warehouse, causing its walls to collapse, but a historic ship was saved.
item.content:encoded: A fire broke out before dawn on San Francisco's Pier 45 and tore through a warehouse, causing its walls to collapse, but a historic ship was saved.

media:content.media:description: First responders battle a massive fire that erupted at a warehouse early Saturday, May 23, 2020 in San Francisco. Arriving crews were confronted with towering flames engulfing the warehouse. (KPIX-TV CBS-Viacom via AP)

item.title: Magnitude 3.0 earthquake registered near Clovis, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.0 earthquake was reported Friday night 54 miles from Clovis, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.0 earthquake was reported Friday night 54 miles from Clovis, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

media:content.media:description: A 3.0-magnitude earthquake struck near Clovis, Calif., on May 23, 2020.

item.title: California elections officials suggest schools as voting sites for social distancing
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Elections officials from across California say they could use schools for voting this fall if campuses could close from Friday, Oct. 30 through Wednesday, Nov. 4.
item.content:encoded: Elections officials from across California say they could use schools for voting this fall if campuses could close from Friday, Oct. 30 through Wednesday, Nov. 4.

media:content.media:description: A voter fills in his ballot at a polling station in Sherman Oaks on May 21, 2013, the city of Los Angeles' election day.

item.title: Mosques adapt to coronavirus shutdown by sharing the call to prayer. In Culver City, neighbors said it was too loud
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Cities across Southern California have allowed mosques to broadcast the call to prayer publicly. But in Culver City, the adhan did not go unchallenged for long.
item.content:encoded: Cities across Southern California have allowed mosques to broadcast the call to prayer publicly. But in Culver City, the adhan did not go unchallenged for long.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, CA - MAY 16: Mahmood Nadvi (Cq), left, standing on the rooftop, delivers Islamic call to prayers Adhan, summoning Muslims for obligatory prayers, at King Fahad Mosque in Culver City. In the midst of pandemic lockdown many mosques in Southern California got permission from local authorities to broadcast Adhan. in King Fahad Mosque on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Culver City, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As coronavirus stay-at-home restrictions ease, California casinos gamble on reopening
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: On Friday, casinos across Southern California opened their doors to gamblers as some lockdown restrictions are softened.
item.content:encoded: On Friday, casinos across Southern California opened their doors to gamblers as some lockdown restrictions are softened.

media:content.media:description: CABAZON, CA - MAY 22, 2020: Patrons get their temperatures taken upon entering Morongo Casino which is reopening for the first time since closing on March 17 because of the coronavirus pandemic on May 22, 2020 in Cabazon, California. Patrons are required to wear masks. The casino reached full capacity within three hours of opening.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Card clubs offer reopening plan as tribal and Vegas casinos get back in the game
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Coronavirus: Card clubs are working on protocols for reopening
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: Card clubs are working on protocols for reopening

media:content.media:description: HAWAIIAN GARDENS CA. AUGUST 23, 2016: Card players try their luck at The Gardens Casino in Hawaiian Gardens on August 23, 2016. The Gardens Casino has undergone a $90-million overhaul and expansion. The card club previously operated out of a smaller tent. The tiny city of Hawaiian Gardens hopes the new card club will bring it added revenue. (Glenn Koenig/ Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Glenn Koenig/ Los Angeles Times / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column: First one death in the family, then another, and the toll kept mounting for Inglewood couple
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: A healthcare activist has seen a grim example of healthcare disparities in his own family's COVID-19 tragedies
item.content:encoded: A healthcare activist has seen a grim example of healthcare disparities in his own family's COVID-19 tragedies

media:content.media:description: INGLEWOOD, CA - MAY 22: Holding a photo depicting members of his extended family, Tony Wafford poses for a portrait outside his home on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Inglewood, CA. Wafford, a healthcare educator at Oasis Clinic at Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital and his wife Diane Walker a retired Sheriff commander have lost relatives to COVID19 in a little more than a week. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Marin's health officer developed antibodies. He's now in a unique spot to fight coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Marin County's public health officer, Matt Willis, got coronavirus. Now recovered, he has ideas on how to help Marin County residents face the disease.
item.content:encoded: Marin County's public health officer, Matt Willis, got coronavirus. Now recovered, he has ideas on how to help Marin County residents face the disease.

media:content.media:description: Matt Willis, Marin County's Public Health Officer, sits in a meeting room with mask and banana peel at the ready, in San Rafael, Calif, on May 19, 2020.

item.title: Column One: They survived a school shooting. Then coronavirus stole Saugus High's senior year
item.dc:creator: Marisa Gerber
item.description: When Adam Bratt studied the faces of his Advanced Placement psychology students that morning in December, he saw trauma.
item.content:encoded: When Adam Bratt studied the faces of his Advanced Placement psychology students that morning in December, he saw trauma.

media:content.media:description: SANTA CLARITIA, CALIFORNIA—NOV. 17, 2019—Students say the Pledge of Allegience as thousands gather at Central Park in Santa Clarita to remember those killed (two plus the shooter) and wounded in the Saugus High School shooting on Nov. 17 2019. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Teaching the coronavirus outbreak in Los Angeles as a crash course in crisis management
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: Former L.A. County Supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky turns a UCLA graduate seminar into a crash course in coronavirus crisis management
item.content:encoded: Former L.A. County Supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky turns a UCLA graduate seminar into a crash course in coronavirus crisis management

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA NOVEMBER 20, 2014 -- Zev Yaroslavsky, member of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors on the rooftop balcony at the County Hall of Administration office on November 20, 2014 as he is preparing to leave the office he was elected to in 1994. Yaroslavsky served on the Los Angeles City Council from 1975 to 1994 and has been active in the areas of transportation, the environment, health care and cultural affairs. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: See's Candies reopens candy kitchens, paying attention to coronavirus concerns

item.description: After shutting down two months ago due to coronavirus concerns, See's Candies is opening up candy kitchens in San Francisco and Los Angeles.
item.content:encoded: After shutting down two months ago due to coronavirus concerns, See's Candies is opening up candy kitchens in San Francisco and Los Angeles.

item.description: Island Express, the charter company that operated the helicopter that crashed in January, killing Kobe Bryant, his daughter and seven others, has received federal support in the midst of COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Island Express, the charter company that operated the helicopter that crashed in January, killing Kobe Bryant, his daughter and seven others, has received federal support in the midst of COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: Pomona City Councilman arrested on child pornography allegations

item.content:encoded: Pomona City Councilman Rubio Gonzalez has been accused of "child annoyance or molestation" and possession of child pornography, authorities said.

item.title: Film producer charged with paying credit cards with coronavirus funds, defrauding investors
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Federal authorities arrested a Beverly Hills film producer on fraud charges after he allegedly paid off his personal credit cards with federal loans intended to help small businesses weather the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Federal authorities arrested a Beverly Hills film producer on fraud charges after he allegedly paid off his personal credit cards with federal loans intended to help small businesses weather the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Los hombres dominan abrumadoramente casi todos los sectores de Hollywood, según un estudio de USC (Mariah Tauger / para The Times).

item.title: Amid 2-day spike in coronavirus deaths, Orange County pushes for wider reopening
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The county submitted final documents Thursday night showing it has met the state's benchmarks to move deeper into Stage 2 of reopening.
item.content:encoded: The county submitted final documents Thursday night showing it has met the state's benchmarks to move deeper into Stage 2 of reopening.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE, CA - MAY 21: Signs hang at Citrus City and Smoqued California BBQ as pedestrians walk by Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Orange. Signmakers - people who paint windows, make banners or A-frames, and other such stuff - has exploded as businesses try everything to get customers during coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Corruption case against former L.A. County Assessor John Noguez tossed by appellate court
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: The former L.A. County assessor was arrested in a 2012 bribery scandal, but an appellate court tossed the long-delayed case Friday after saying prosecutors missed a deadline that was tantamount to a violation of Noguez's right to a speedy trial.
item.content:encoded: The former L.A. County assessor was arrested in a 2012 bribery scandal, but an appellate court tossed the long-delayed case Friday after saying prosecutors missed a deadline that was tantamount to a violation of Noguez's right to a speedy trial.

media:content.media:description: New charges were filed against L.A. County assessor John Noguez, one of his former top aides and a tax consultant.

item.title: Trump administration warns Garcetti against 'heavy-handed' stay-at-home orders
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith, Joseph Serna
item.description: The Trump administration sent a letter to L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti saying the Department of Justice is concerned the city may pursue "an arbitrary and heavy-handed approach" to coronavirus stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration sent a letter to L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti saying the Department of Justice is concerned the city may pursue "an arbitrary and heavy-handed approach" to coronavirus stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: In his daily COVID-19 briefing, Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti lays down plans for beginning phase two of reopening the city, what he called "baby steps forward." He detailed what businesses can reopen and issued guidelines for wearing masks while on trails or golf courses, which can reopen starting Saturday.

item.title: Sacramento County pulls plug on fitness studios, small gatherings after state intervenes

item.content:encoded: State health officials say gyms can't open and gatherings of any size are still forbidden in Sacramento County, even under relaxed restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his plan for the gradual reopening of California businesses during a news conference at the Display California store in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, May 5, 2020. Newsom warned counties that going too far in loosening coronavirus restrictions, could endanger public health. Display California, which sells locally-made items from around the state, is planning to open for curbside service on Friday under upcoming state guidelines. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: How to celebrate Memorial Day during the pandemic

item.description: Memorial Day will be very different in 2020. Instead of large gatherings with friends and family, try some of these alternatives.
item.content:encoded: Memorial Day will be very different in 2020. Instead of large gatherings with friends and family, try some of these alternatives.

(Photo by Jayne Kamin-Oncea/Getty Images)

item.title: Actress Lori Loughlin and her husband enter guilty pleas in college admissions scandal
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin
item.description: After maintaining their innocence for more than a year, Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli plead guilty to fraud in the college admissions scandal.
item.content:encoded: After maintaining their innocence for more than a year, Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli plead guilty to fraud in the college admissions scandal.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 3, 2019 file photo, actress Lori Loughlin, front, and husband, clothing designer Mossimo Giannulli, left, depart federal court in Boston after facing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. Loughlin and her husband Giannulli said in court documents Monday, April 15, 2019, that they are pleading not guilty to charges that they took part in a sweeping college admissions bribery scam. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File)

item.title: Social distancing circles drawn on grass at San Francisco parks
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Four San Francisco parks are being outfitted with social distancing circles to remind people to stay away from each other while outdoors during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Four San Francisco parks are being outfitted with social distancing circles to remind people to stay away from each other while outdoors during the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - MAY 20: New social distancing circles are shown at Dolores Park on May 20, 2020 in San Francisco, California. The move follows similar moves by other parks in cities around the world in an effort to get back to some semblance of normalcy. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

media:content.media:description: Dan Coyro Santa Cruz Sentinel SANTA CRUZ COUNTY sheriff's deputies investigate at the home of Tushar Atre, who was kidnapped and killed Tuesday. Authorities said on Facebook that they believe the crime began as a robbery attempt.

item.title: California's unemployment rate leaps to 15.5% as 2.3 million jobs vanish
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt

item.content:encoded: "We've basically wiped out a decade worth of job creation in a month and a half," an economist says. May's unemployment figures will probably look even grimmer.

media:content.media:description: CANOGA PARK, CA - MAY 14: Maria Mora came to find information about her claim but found the California State Employment Development Department was closed due to coronavirus concerns on Thursday, May 14, 2020 in Canoga Park, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: He's diabetic. He works a high-risk job. But to pay rent, he has no choice
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: During coronavirus, Americans increasingly rely on migrant workers, many in the country illegally, who have no protections or financial support.
item.content:encoded: During coronavirus, Americans increasingly rely on migrant workers, many in the country illegally, who have no protections or financial support.

media:content.media:description: SAN JOSE, CA -- MAY 20: Porfirio, 51, a migrant from Mexico, a diabetic which puts him at higher risk of suffering serious complications and dying from COVID-19, at his home on Wednesday, May 20, 2020, in San Jose, CA. Porfirio is a Bay Area medical maintenance technician earns $27 an hour painting and repairing rooms and hallways in clinics and hospitals, a job that puts him at high risk for catching the coronavirus. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Even as California reopens, some officials tell tourists to stay away
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: More than two-thirds of California's 58 counties have received approval to more quickly reopen as the state continues to loosen coronavirus-related restrictions.
item.content:encoded: More than two-thirds of California's 58 counties have received approval to more quickly reopen as the state continues to loosen coronavirus-related restrictions.

media:content.media:description: MORRO BAY CA. APRIL 2, 2019 - April 2019 of otters floating in the marina at Morro Bay in San Luis Obispo County. San Luis Obispo County's health officer Dr. Penny Borenstein has asked tourists to not visit as the county reopens shops and restaurants this week. (Marc Martin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: SpongeBob Popsicles, anyone? Parents compel ice cream vendor forced indoors to 'come back'
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: Ed Hassan put the brakes on his ice cream truck business when the COVID-19 pandemic hit. Parents in north Orange County convinced him to return.
item.content:encoded: Ed Hassan put the brakes on his ice cream truck business when the COVID-19 pandemic hit. Parents in north Orange County convinced him to return.

media:content.media:description: TUSTIN, CA - MAY 20: Ed Hassan, the owner of Mr. Frost Ice Cream truck, makes his rounds selling ice cream, popsicles and snacks on Wednesday, May 20, 2020 in Tustin, CA. Hassan had been on lockdown for about six weeks, he took the time to repaint and reorganize his cargo van. But parents kept calling and calling him, he said, asking for entire boxes of Sponge Bob popsicles and begging him to come back. "I thought they wanted me at home so I was at home. But there are huge demands." (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gov. Gavin Newsom's promise to feed California seniors falling short so far
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom's program to deliver meals to California seniors hasn't lived up to his projections.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom's program to deliver meals to California seniors hasn't lived up to his projections.

media:content.media:description: ALHAMBRA, CA - MAY 20: Mildred ``Millie'' Stratton waves to a caravan of cars led by the Alhambra Police and Fire parading past her home, celebrating her 102nd birthday on Wednesday, May 20, 2020 in Alhambra, CA. Millie is actively a lay leader and sits on several committees at the First United Methodist Church in Alhambra. Millie, who has lived in Alhambra her whole life within two blocks, has three children, one of whom died, four grandchildren and three great grandchildren. When asked what she attributed her long life to, Millie answered, "A hundred years ago the air was clean, the water was clean we had no problem and my mother was an excellent nutritionist, and we had home-grown chickens. And so we had so much chicken, I didn't cook it for ten years after I was married. Because that's' what we could raise. Just about two blocks from here. It was a small town. We knew everybody. Now that's all changed." Millie says she also credits her faith in God and support and help from friends and family. Millie was asked to offer her words of advice: "Well, it's easy to say, you have to live each day without the stress." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: As L.A. County deaths pass 2,000, a warning that 'the virus is still out there waiting'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Rong-Gong Lin II, Hannah Fry
item.description: Los Angeles County accounts for nearly 60% of the state's total COVID-19 deaths
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County accounts for nearly 60% of the state's total COVID-19 deaths

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In a pandemic, no one wants to touch it. Why cash has become the new Typhoid Mary
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: Many retailers and consumers fear handling dollars and cents during the coronavirus pandemic. Some experts say it will accelerate the transition to a cash-free U.S. economy.
item.content:encoded: Many retailers and consumers fear handling dollars and cents during the coronavirus pandemic. Some experts say it will accelerate the transition to a cash-free U.S. economy.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 20: Maricela Moreno, manager at El Tarasco in Marina del Rey, disinfects cash at the restaurant. She said a lot of customers pay with Apple Pay or credit cards. Marina del Rey on Wednesday, May 20, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Big Bear Lake to stop communicating or enforcing state's coronavirus stay-at-home order
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The city of Big Bear Lake no longer plans to communicate or enforce Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at-home health order, stating that it has no legal responsibility to impose the state's restrictions on residents.
item.content:encoded: The city of Big Bear Lake no longer plans to communicate or enforce Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at-home health order, stating that it has no legal responsibility to impose the state's restrictions on residents.

media:content.media:description: Big Bear Lake offers visitors who stay at the mountain resort town a discount on summer activities like a round of golf or a ride on Snow Summit's lift.

item.title: Sections of L.A. River to reopen for limited activities
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Fishing, bird watching and walking will be permitted in the Elysian Valley and in the Sepulveda Basin in Encino. Kayaking and other in-water activities will be forbidden.
item.content:encoded: Fishing, bird watching and walking will be permitted in the Elysian Valley and in the Sepulveda Basin in Encino. Kayaking and other in-water activities will be forbidden.

media:content.media:description: An ibis forages for food in the Los Angeles River near Long Beach. The river and the 225-acre Sepulveda Basin Wildlife Reserve that drains into it also are occasional resting spots for migratory birds. www.lariver.org/
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Autopsies of 34 who died in Conception boat fire offer grim new details
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Deadly Conception dive boat fire, coroner's records raise new questions over deaths
item.content:encoded: Deadly Conception dive boat fire, coroner's records raise new questions over deaths

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Coast Guard was involved in a massive rescue operation Monday morning after a 75-foot commercial diving boat caught fire off the coast of Ventura County, trapping dozens of people.More than 30 people were missing and officials said some died. Many on the boat, which was off Santa Cruz Island, were believed to be sleeping below deck when the fire broke out and appear to have been trapped.

item.title: Cleanup to resume at troubled Santa Susana Field Laboratory site
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: After years of delay, the federal government will resume environmental cleanup at a former nuclear and rocket test site in the hills of Ventura County
item.content:encoded: After years of delay, the federal government will resume environmental cleanup at a former nuclear and rocket test site in the hills of Ventura County

media:content.media:description: A view of an inactive space shuttle test location at the Santa Susana Field Laboratory site in 2002. Most of the Simi Valley, California, property is owned by Boeing, which acquired Rocketdyne in 1996. (Los Angeles Times/MCT) ** HOY OUT, TCN OUT **

item.title: As sheriff defies subpoena on jails, watchdog plans another for Kobe Bryant crash records
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: The subpoena is part of an inquiry into whether L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva covered up the sharing of graphic photos by deputies. Villanueva did not show at a meeting where he was called to testify on coronavirus in jails.
item.content:encoded: The subpoena is part of an inquiry into whether L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva covered up the sharing of graphic photos by deputies. Villanueva did not show at a meeting where he was called to testify on coronavirus in jails.

media:content.media:description: This image taken from video on Monday, Jan. 27, 2020, and provided by the National Transportation Safety Board, shows part of the wreckage of a helicopter crash near Calabasas, Calif. The Sunday, Jan. 26 crash killed former NBA basketball player Kobe Bryant, his 13-year-old daughter, Gianna, and seven others. (James Anderson/National Transportation Safety Board via AP)

item.title: Some California courts start to reopen as coronavirus restrictions ease
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Among the California counties reopening courts: Contra Costa, Santa Clara, Monterey
item.content:encoded: Among the California counties reopening courts: Contra Costa, Santa Clara, Monterey

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 21: The Stanley Mosk Superior Court in downtown Los Angeles is photographed on Saturday, March 21, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Earlier in the week, California Governor Gavin Newsom issued a "Safer at Home" order to the entire state to help slow the spread of the Coronavirus as it sweeps across the world. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County reopens dine-in restaurants and in-store shopping
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Ventura County has received state permission to reopen restaurants for dining in and to allow shopping inside many retail stores.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County has received state permission to reopen restaurants for dining in and to allow shopping inside many retail stores.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Cal Youngblood, 75, is served breakfast by owner Raymundo Sanchez at Busy Bee Cafe on Main Street in downtown Ventura Thursday morning as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Clay drove from Simi Valley to eat at Busy Bee Cafe for the first time in months as the restaurant holds special memories because his Mother worked there for many years in the 1960's. "I couldn't wait to come back." He said. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Popular trails prepare for massive crowds over Memorial Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: At least two popular areas in Southern California are closing amid increased crowds while stay-at-home orders continue to be relaxed.
item.content:encoded: At least two popular areas in Southern California are closing amid increased crowds while stay-at-home orders continue to be relaxed.

media:content.media:description: Highway 33 winds through the mountains of the Los Padres National Forest in Ventura County.
media:content.media:credit: Michael Robinson Chavez / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Orange County reports highest daily death toll from coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Orange County recorded 14 new coronavirus-related fatalities Thursday, an uptick that officials attribute to outbreaks of the virus in nursing homes.
item.content:encoded: Orange County recorded 14 new coronavirus-related fatalities Thursday, an uptick that officials attribute to outbreaks of the virus in nursing homes.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - MAY 18: Families practice social distancing while playing in the water and sand near the San Clemente Pier on Monday, May 18, 2020 in San Clemente, CA. Orange County beaches are currently open for active recreation, which includes swimming, surfing, and running. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Proposed budget cuts threaten safe opening of California schools, leaders say
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli
item.description: coronavirus: Officials doubt schools can reopen safely if they must cut budgets
item.content:encoded: coronavirus: Officials doubt schools can reopen safely if they must cut budgets

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2018 photo, Assemblyman Tony Thurmond, D-Richmond, a candidate for Superintendent of Public Instruction, appears at a candidates debate hosted by the Sacramento Press Club in Sacramento, Calif. Thurmond is running against Marshall Tuck, a former charter schools executive. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: UC makes landmark decision to drop ACT and SAT requirement for admission
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: UC regents vote to suspend SAT and ACT testing requirements for admission, marking a turning point in the debate over standardized test scores.
item.content:encoded: UC regents vote to suspend SAT and ACT testing requirements for admission, marking a turning point in the debate over standardized test scores.

media:content.media:description: PEMBROKE PINES, FL - MARCH 06: A college applicant uses an SAT Preparation book to study for the test on March 6, 2014 in Pembroke Pines, Florida.

item.title: California lawmakers say state unemployment help still isn't coming fast enough amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Legislators criticize the state Employment Development Department, citing phone and computer problems. Agency's director says incoming funding will help.
item.content:encoded: Legislators criticize the state Employment Development Department, citing phone and computer problems. Agency's director says incoming funding will help.

media:content.media:description: California employers added 45,800 jobs in October. The unemployment rate dipped slightly to 10.1% from 10.2%. Above, applicants at a job fair in Concord, Calif.

item.title: Yosemite may reopen in June, with half the number of visitors, ticketed entry
item.dc:creator: Mary Forgione
item.description: Lodgings and some campgrounds would reopen under a draft plan that still requires approval from the state and the feds.
item.content:encoded: Lodgings and some campgrounds would reopen under a draft plan that still requires approval from the state and the feds.

media:content.media:description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, CA - APRIL 11: Yosemite Falls seen without people due to the park closure on April 11, 2020. The trail is empty leading to Yosemite Falls in Yosemite Park due to the closure. Yosemite National Park is closed to visitors due to the coronavirus, Covid 19. Animals roam the park without having to worry about crowds of people. Madera County on Saturday, April 11, 2020 in Yosemite National Park, CA. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Carolyn Cole/Carolyn Cole/Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 8 arrested during protest over coronavirus restrictions in San Clemente
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: About 200 protesters converged near the pier to demand that stay-at-home rules in California be lifted and San Clemente officials remove fencing enclosing a beach parking lot.
item.content:encoded: About 200 protesters converged near the pier to demand that stay-at-home rules in California be lifted and San Clemente officials remove fencing enclosing a beach parking lot.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 2020: An aerial view of the previously closed San Clemente pier and now closed San Clemente beach, which was closed to help curb the spread of the coronavirus in San Clemente, CA, on April 8, 2020. Officials said the Orange County Sheriff's Department, Marine Safety, Code Enforcement and Park Rangers will increase monitoring and people who do not comply could be cited. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Hollywood Hills land sale makes Griffith Park a bit bigger
item.dc:creator: Jack Flemming
item.description: A community fundraiser recently raised $500,000 to buy two parcels adjacent to Griffith Park, ensuring the land will not be developed.
item.content:encoded: A community fundraiser recently raised $500,000 to buy two parcels adjacent to Griffith Park, ensuring the land will not be developed.

media:content.media:description: Griffith Observatory can be seen from one of the higher trails in the park, which is more than 4,200 acres.
media:content.media:credit: Michael Robinson Chavez / Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County surpasses 2,000 coronavirus deaths: 'A very sad milestone'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Leila Miller, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: The county's fatalities account for nearly 60% of the COVID-19 deaths in the state, which has recorded more than 3,500 deaths.
item.content:encoded: The county's fatalities account for nearly 60% of the COVID-19 deaths in the state, which has recorded more than 3,500 deaths.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Tuesday, May 19, 2020 - People walk, jog and bike past Evergreen Cemetery as local stay at home orders are increasingly relaxed months into the Covid-19 pandemic. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County extends beach hours for Memorial Day weekend, reopens some parking lots
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Seal Beach, Huntington Beach and Newport Beach are now open daily from before sun-up to past dawn. Laguna Beach is keeping stricter weekend times, closing midday.
item.content:encoded: Seal Beach, Huntington Beach and Newport Beach are now open daily from before sun-up to past dawn. Laguna Beach is keeping stricter weekend times, closing midday.

media:content.media:description: SEAL BEACH-CA-MAY 21, 2020: Beach goers enjoy a day at Seal Beach while social distancing on Thursday, May 21, 2020, as the city of Seal Beach extends the hours they are open. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 40 of California's 58 counties get OK for more robust reopening
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Ventura and San Diego counties are among the latest to get state approval to push through Phase 2. Orange County hasn't been given the green light yet, and L.A. County doesn't meet the criteria.
item.content:encoded: Ventura and San Diego counties are among the latest to get state approval to push through Phase 2. Orange County hasn't been given the green light yet, and L.A. County doesn't meet the criteria.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Roger Anderson and son Trey, 11, enjoy breakfast served by Nora Nancy at Busy Bee Cafe on Main Street in downtown Ventura Thursday morning as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. "This is one of our favorite paces to eat so we made a point to swing in." Said Roger. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County achieves major coronavirus win as transmission rate hits lowest level
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: An increasing downturn in the daily number of new cases suggests the transmission number is slightly under 1, a milestone for L.A. County.
item.content:encoded: An increasing downturn in the daily number of new cases suggests the transmission number is slightly under 1, a milestone for L.A. County.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, CA-MAY 14, 2020: Lindsay Rojas, 28, owner of Lindsay's Dog Walks in Culver City, walks Gomez, left, and Nikki, brother and sister Golden Retrievers, on Le Bourget Ave. in Culver City. The dogs belong to an elderly woman named Riya who has multiple sclerosis. During the coronavirus pandemic, experts warn that dogs should not interact with other dogs outside their immediate family. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Online child sex abuse reports surge as kids spend more time on computers amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Law enforcement has been overwhelmed by a massive surge in tips about online child sexual abuse and exploitation tied coronavirus at-home learning.
item.content:encoded: Law enforcement has been overwhelmed by a massive surge in tips about online child sexual abuse and exploitation tied coronavirus at-home learning.

item.title: Lori Loughlin always insisted she was innocent in admissions scandal. Why change now?
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Lori Loughlin and husband Mossimo Giannulli's guilty plea announcement marks a major moment in the scandal that rocked American academia.
item.content:encoded: Lori Loughlin and husband Mossimo Giannulli's guilty plea announcement marks a major moment in the scandal that rocked American academia.

media:content.media:description: Actress Lori Loughlin, front, and husband, clothing designer Mossimo Giannulli, rear, depart federal court in Boston on Wednesday, April 3, 2019, after facing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. (AP Photo/Charles Krupa)

item.title: Pulling dollar bills off the wall to keep going in rural California
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: As the coronavirus lockdown severs commerce along the eastern Sierra Nevada range, rural towns look to the future with dread.
item.content:encoded: As the coronavirus lockdown severs commerce along the eastern Sierra Nevada range, rural towns look to the future with dread.

media:content.media:description: LONE PINE, CA - MAY 07: Jake's Saloon owners Sherri Newman, right, and Forrest Newman, left, chat inside the temporarily closed bar on Main St. Thursday, May 7, 2020 in Lone Pine, CA. Newman and employees removed thousands of dollar bills left by customers over the years and divided up the cash as a bonus since the closure has limited their income. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Lori Loughlin to plead guilty in college admissions scandal, faces 2 months in prison
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Lori Loughlin will plead guilty for her role in the college admissions scandal. She faces 2 months in prison.
item.content:encoded: Lori Loughlin will plead guilty for her role in the college admissions scandal. She faces 2 months in prison.

media:content.media:description: Actress Lori Loughlin and husband Mossimo Giannulli exit the Boston Federal Court house after a pre-trial hearing with Magistrate Judge Kelley at the John Joseph Moakley US Courthouse in Boston on Aug. 27, 2019. (Joseph Prezioso/AFP/Getty Images/TNS) ** OUTS - ELSENT, FPG, TCN - OUTS **

item.title: New UC Merced chancellor is a farmworker's son and UC alum
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Juan Sánchez Muñoz, 53, the son of a Joaquin Valley farmworker, has been named the new chancellor of UC Merced. Muñoz will lead the youngest and most diverse UC campus.
item.content:encoded: Juan Sánchez Muñoz, 53, the son of a Joaquin Valley farmworker, has been named the new chancellor of UC Merced. Muñoz will lead the youngest and most diverse UC campus.

media:content.media:description: Juan Sanchez Munoz has been named new UC Merced chancellor. (UC Merced)

item.title: Coronavirus in Tijuana: Paramedics risk their lives to help the sick
item.dc:creator: Marcus Yam, Ruben Vives
item.description: The coronavirus is killing so many people in Tijuana that the morgue has run out of refrigerator space for bodies.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus is killing so many people in Tijuana that the morgue has run out of refrigerator space for bodies.

media:content.media:description: TIJUANA, BAJA CALIFORNIA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 29, 2020: As Sergio Garcia stands in the doorway to calmly explain the next steps after death, Georgina Barajas Rios, grieves for her mother who just passed away, Maria Ruiz Olmedo, 71, after she suffered from symptoms that match COVID-19 symptoms, at their home, in Tijuana, Mexico, on April 29, 2020. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Lockdowns crippled his 'bouncy house' business. Nearly bankrupt, he's pushing back
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Jim Edmonds' party rental business was hit when gatherings were restricted to stem the COVID-19 pandemic. With no relief in site, he's turned to protests.
item.content:encoded: Jim Edmonds' party rental business was hit when gatherings were restricted to stem the COVID-19 pandemic. With no relief in site, he's turned to protests.

media:content.media:description: Jim Edmonds runs a bouncey house rental company near Sacramento. The shutdown has driven him close to bankruptcy, pushing him to join rallies at the state capitol. He was arrested at one on May 1, but returned for days later for another. He is pictured here standing at the Capitol, where CHP officers formed a line to keep protesters out.

item.title: Skelton: Newsom wise to end one-man rule on coronavirus, giving local leaders more discretion
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Newsom has wisely relented on his coronavirus restrictions. There's no need to get into the equivalent of a shooting war with rural communities — especially those in the far north, where many people resent being part of California anyway.
item.content:encoded: Newsom has wisely relented on his coronavirus restrictions. There's no need to get into the equivalent of a shooting war with rural communities — especially those in the far north, where many people resent being part of California anyway.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom announces new criteria related to coronavirus hospitalizations and testing that could allow counties to open faster than the state, during a news conference at Mustards Grill in Napa, Calif., Monday May 18, 2020. Newsom says the new criteria could apply to 53 of the state's 58 counties. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: California prisons to begin accepting inmates as coronavirus deaths mount in Chino
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton

item.content:encoded: After a two-month hold on the intake of new inmates amid the coronavirus pandemic, California's prisons are expected to resume processing next week.

media:content.media:description: Betty Broderick who killed her ex-husband, Daniel T. Broderick III, and his wife, Linda Kolkena Broderick in 1989, asked a parole board to be released at the California Institution for Women Chino on Thursday. (K.C. Alfred/Union-Tribune)

item.title: L.A. sheriff will defy subpoena from oversight commission on jail conditions
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva said he refuses to testify before the civilian oversight board on jail safety during the novel coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva said he refuses to testify before the civilian oversight board on jail safety during the novel coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Dec. 3, 2018 file photo newly-elected Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva speaks during a swearing-in ceremony in Monterey Park, Calif. Villanueva will limit when inmates in the county's jails can be transferred to federal authorities for deportation. Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Nicole Nishida said on Friday, Feb. 15, 2019, the agency will reduce the number of misdemeanor charges that can trigger an inmate's transfer. She could not immediately say which misdemeanor charges would no longer qualify. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong, File)

item.title: Larry Aubry, black activist icon and 'godfather of South Central Los Angeles,' dies
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: The conscience of black L.A., Aubry wrote a column for the Los Angeles Sentinel for 33 years.
item.content:encoded: The conscience of black L.A., Aubry wrote a column for the Los Angeles Sentinel for 33 years.

media:content.media:description: Larry Aubry, 73, is a columnist with the Los Angeles Sentinel and a longtime community activist.

item.title: Despite many coronavirus deaths, Tulare County vows to defy Newsom and further reopen
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, James Rainey
item.description: The Tulare County Board of Supervisors voted to push the county all the way through Phase 3 of California's reopening road map.
item.content:encoded: The Tulare County Board of Supervisors voted to push the county all the way through Phase 3 of California's reopening road map.

media:content.media:description: Yvonne Wright, right, shops for shoes with the help of sales person Jennifer Blythe-Freiner at Brown's Shoe Fit Co., Wednesday, May 20, 2020, in Visalia, Calif. Tulare County's board of supervisors voted 3-2 Tuesday to move further into the state's four-stage reopening plan than is allowed. That means nearly all businesses and churches could reopen, though county officials said businesses should adhere to state guidelines on social distancing and other health measures. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)

item.title: L.A. city and county fight over how to shelter homeless people living near freeways
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: A hearing about the moving of homeless people living near freeways was canceled after L.A. city and county couldn't agree to a plan to work together on how to proceed.
item.content:encoded: A hearing about the moving of homeless people living near freeways was canceled after L.A. city and county couldn't agree to a plan to work together on how to proceed.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA MAY 19, 2020-Homeless people line up tents along Figueroa St. under the 101 Freeway in Downtown Los Angeles Tuesday. Thousands of homeless people living near freeways in L.A. County are in line to receive alternative shelter during the COVID-19 pandemic. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Most California school districts plan to open in the fall. Here's how it would work
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: Tony Thurmond, California's superintendent of schools, has updated the public on safely reopening schools in the fall.
item.content:encoded: Tony Thurmond, California's superintendent of schools, has updated the public on safely reopening schools in the fall.

media:content.media:description: A young protester holds a sign asking for schools to be opened during protest to open the state of California, at Pier Plaza in Huntington Beach on Saturday, May 9, 2020.

item.title: Earthquake: 3.6 quake near Ridgecrest
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A 3.6 earthquake was reported at 9:40 a.m. Wednesday six miles from Ridgecrest, Calif.
item.content:encoded: A 3.6 earthquake was reported at 9:40 a.m. Wednesday six miles from Ridgecrest, Calif.

media:content.media:description: A 3.6 earthquake was reported at 9:40 a.m. May 20 six miles from Ridgecrest, Calif.

item.title: A new high for coronavirus deaths in California as counties push ahead with reopening
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money
item.description: California reported 132 new coronavirus-related fatalities Tuesday — the most in a single day — as counties move forward with plans to reopen.
item.content:encoded: California reported 132 new coronavirus-related fatalities Tuesday — the most in a single day — as counties move forward with plans to reopen.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Alfredo Contreras, left, is getting the oral swab test for coronavirus from Family Nurse Practitioner Anniesatu Newland at walk-in coronavirus testing at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles, one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by coronavirus. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: WWE reacts to the death of former pro wrestler Shad Gaspard
item.dc:creator: Chuck Schilken
item.description: Figures from around the WWE react to the death of former wrestler Shad Gaspard, whose body was found early Wednesday near the Venice Pier.
item.content:encoded: Figures from around the WWE react to the death of former wrestler Shad Gaspard, whose body was found early Wednesday near the Venice Pier.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this July 15, 2013, file photo, professional wrestler Shad Gaspard attens the 8th Annual BTE All-Star Celebrity Kickoff Party at the Playboy Mansion in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Los Angeles Police Department says a body found on Venice Beach early Wednesday, May 20, 2020 is that of former World Wrestling Entertainment pro Shad Gaspard. He went missing in the water while swimming with his son last weekend. (Photo by Paul A. Hebert/Invision/AP, File)

item.title: A big push to reopen restaurants, malls, even gyms ASAP. But it's not that simple
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Kailyn Brown, Sarah Parvini, Charles T. Carter
item.description: New rules will allow restaurant dining rooms and shopping malls to open in counties that meet new criteria.
item.content:encoded: New rules will allow restaurant dining rooms and shopping malls to open in counties that meet new criteria.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - MAY 19: An aerial view of Bella Terra Mall on Tuesday, May 19, 2020 in Huntington Beach, CA. The day after Gov. Gavin Newsom cracked the door for more counties to potentially lift additional coronavirus-related restrictions, Orange County officials made it clear that they want to get through as quickly as possible. Officials hope to see larger parts of the retail economy - including shopping malls and restaurants - reopen with social distancing restrictions as soon as possible. While health officials said they are still planning how to move further into what the state calls Phase 2, members of the Board of Supervisors said Tuesday that time is of the essence. "We can put together a plan, and I'm still keeping my fingers crossed," said Supervisor Andrew Do. "I'm hoping that by this weekend, we're going to enter Phase 2 fully.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Inside the Trump fight with California over opening churches amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Alex Wigglesworth, Laura Newberry
item.description: The Justice Department warns that stay-at-home measures enacted by California's governor may discriminate against religious groups and violate their rights.
item.content:encoded: The Justice Department warns that stay-at-home measures enacted by California's governor may discriminate against religious groups and violate their rights.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 10: Archbishop Jose Gomez, left, celebrates Good Friday liturgy in a nearly empty Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels to guard against the coronavirus on Friday, April 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Body of former pro wrestler Shad Gaspard found near Venice Pier
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Shad Gaspard, 39, had been missing since Sunday afternoon when he was swept out to sea at Venice Beach. His body was found early Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: Shad Gaspard, 39, had been missing since Sunday afternoon when he was swept out to sea at Venice Beach. His body was found early Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: En foto de archivo del 28 de junio del 2015 Shad Gaspard en la alfombra roja de la premier de Teminator Genisys en Los Ángeles. El 19 de mayo del 2020 el exluchador profesional de la WWE Shad Gaspard sigue desaparecido este martes después de que fue arrastrado por las olas sur de California el fin de semana mientras nadaba con su pequeño hijo. (Photo by Rich Fury/Invision/AP, archivo)

item.title: L.A. Fire Department to inspect vape and smoke shops after downtown explosion
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, James Queally
item.description: The Los Angeles Fire Department will launch a review of the way vape and tobacco shops store volatile substances after an explosion downtown seriously injured several firefighters.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Fire Department will launch a review of the way vape and tobacco shops store volatile substances after an explosion downtown seriously injured several firefighters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MAY 18, 2020. Members of the Los Angeles Fire Department investigate the scene of a fiery explosion on Boyd St. in the downtown los Angeles Toy District that injured 12 firefighters and damaged buildings and fire equipment, authorities said. The explosion happened around 6:30 pm Saturday, when firefighters responded to the initial call of a fire in the single-story building at 327 Boyd St., between Third and Fourth Streets. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times

item.title: ICE said a 74-year-old was too dangerous to release. He died of apparent suicide
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Choung Woong Ahn's family said he should be released because of his age and health issues. ICE disagreed.
item.content:encoded: Choung Woong Ahn's family said he should be released because of his age and health issues. ICE disagreed.

media:content.media:description: Choung Woong Ahn, 74, died by suicide at the Mesa Verde ICE Processing Center in Bakersfield.
media:content.media:credit: Courtesy of Priya Patel/Courtesy of Priya Patel

item.title: Here's a closer look at the ex-deputy mayor enmeshed in City Hall corruption probe
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Joel Rubin
item.description: Prosecutors alleged that a deputy mayor was paid by a real estate consultant to help shepherd a major project through L.A. City Hall — and leveraged his power as a city official to aid the development.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors alleged that a deputy mayor was paid by a real estate consultant to help shepherd a major project through L.A. City Hall — and leveraged his power as a city official to aid the development.

media:content.media:description: Raymond Chan, left, and Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti
media:content.media:credit: Los Angeles Department of Building and Safety; AP

item.title: California is finally making progress in the coronavirus battle, even as deaths keep rising
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Sean Greene
item.description: Three months into California's battle with the coronavirus, there are growing signs that the outbreak is ebbing even as the state death toll continues to climb past 3,400.
item.content:encoded: Three months into California's battle with the coronavirus, there are growing signs that the outbreak is ebbing even as the state death toll continues to climb past 3,400.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Destiny VanSciner, 32, left, is getting the oral swab test for coronavirus from Family Nurse Practitioner Anniesatu Newland at walk-in coronavirus testing at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles, one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by coronavirus. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: I got tested for COVID-19. Should you?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: L.A. County has made free testing available to anyone who wants it, symptoms or not. Is that good public policy?
item.content:encoded: L.A. County has made free testing available to anyone who wants it, symptoms or not. Is that good public policy?

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MARCH 26, 2020: Members of the Los Angeles Fire Dept. wear protective gear while handing out kits to people to swab the inside of their mouths to test for the coronavirus, inside a parking lot on Stadium Way, near Dodger Stadium. Cars in background are drivers, waiting in what was over a 2 hour line, by appointment only to be tested. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)
